topic.title: Useing a SOCKS proxy with authentication.
topic.body:
I wanted to set my VPN's socks proxy for connecting to trackers, But it looks like there is no way to enter the username and password. I'm not going to use the un:pw@vpnproxy.net trick for obvious reasons.

Is there a way to do this in the config?

topic.title: No Proxy for localhost in tor is insecure?
topic.body:
https://www.reddit.com/r/TOR/comments/4lj2da/tor_unable_to_connect_localhost/

Aparently this reddit user thinks that setting up No Proxy for 127.0.0.1 is not a good idea, and proceeds to link to the following.

https://blog.jetbrains.com/blog/2016/05/11/security-update-for-intellij-based-ides-v2016-1-and-older-versions/

He just says. "Don't do that" and gives that site as an exsample, but does not expand on why. Is it a consern over Cross-Site Request Forgery (CSRF)?

I'm confused... Hopefully someone can give some insight.

topic.title: Self Destructing/Locking down ZeroNet.
topic.body:
As good as zero net is for our freedom, there remains a legal problem.

Most authorities do not care if the data was automatically pulled from Zero, or if you actively even was aware the content was on your HDD. The fact that something illegal was on your HDD is enough for them to say you knew, so they can chuck you into the legal grinder, Were a stuffy old judge that does not understand technology will chuck the book at you for being a degenerate. 

We all know that innocent until proven guilty is dead, and Authorities operate on the flawed thinking of "you have nothing to fear if you have nothing to hide".

So, we need a method that allows the storing of ZeroNet data in a way that meets the following conditions.

A. It is not stored in a legible manner on your HDD.
B. It can be destroyed in a way that is quick, so the entire data does not have to be zeroed or Gutmanned.
C. Destruction is not detectable, so you are not charged with destruction of evidence.
D. It is able to pass plausible deniability.
E. Can pass the handing over of a password, so you are not charged with obstruction or contempt.
F. Does not require full disk encryption with a hidden system OS, as the point is to seed all the time, and the clean OS needs to be used constantly for deniability’s sake.

Veracript is obvious, But, I'm worried the problem with this is that the browser and the OS will leave foot prints behind that shows that the hidden volume existed in logs. Or, in the free space data that the authorities could grab if they felt the need to take it to the forensics lab after there donut brake.

So, I'm thinking that we could have a Linux distro VM with LUKS set up in a way to have a fake and a hidden volume. It is not that unusual for People to have VM's that they do not do very much with. E.G Just have it as a toy they played with, or just testing it out.

If we use a privacy distro that inherently wipes its self after each reboot, The fact the VM fake boot password has nothing can not be considered suspicious at all. However, The reel VM boot is where your ZeroNet is actually run within, and is where the data is kept. Running this in a VM allows you to host Zero net in its own environment, and, gives you the ability to just give the police the fake PW in that unlikely event you got your IP pegged that one time you was careless, or, a vulnerability was found that allowed Zites to leek your real location.

There are also ways to get LUKS to delete its keys when requiered, so, for added peace of mind, you could have a way for the ZeroNet volume to Nuke it's keys in a quick manor and reboot, forever rendering that part of the data forever destroyed.

topic.title: Now your entering the twilight zone.
Lets get formmatting!
topic.body:
# _**Tested as working formatting tags you can use on ZT.**_

### ------------------------------------ References ------------------------------------ 

[OP][1]
[OP][2]
[1]:Faggot
[2]:Still_A_Faggot

```
[OP][1]
[OP][2]
[1]:Faggot
[2]:Still_A_Faggot
```

## _**You can use this to do comment/element jumping**_

Click reply and take the (#comment) string and use that as the reference.

[EG][3]
[3]:#comment_48_16YKCPxCUyjP3zF1CNtsWCHu44ToaNZJYM
```
[EG][3]
[3]:#comment_48_16YKCPxCUyjP3zF1CNtsWCHu44ToaNZJYM
```
If you want to jump to an element, use inspect element in your browser to find its id in the code. copy the id string, paste it as your Reference and add a "#" to the beginning.

E.G.

Don't forget to leave a [comment][4]
[4]:#comment_body

```
Don't forget to leave a [comment][4]
[4]:#comment_body
```

### ------------------------------------------ List ------------------------------------------

- a
- b
- c

```
- a 
- b
- c
```

### -------------------------------------- Num List --------------------------------------

1. a
2. b
3. c

```
1. a
2. b
3. c
```

### -------------------------------------- Code line ---------------------------------------- 

`code line`

``` `code line` ```

### ------------------------------------ Code block --------------------------------------

```
code
block
```

` ``` `
`code`
`block`
` ``` `
### ----------------------------------------- Link --------------------------------------------

[link](http://youaregay.com/)

```
[link](http://youaregay.com/)
```
Yes, that is actually a working site.

### ---------------------------------------- Quote -------------------------------------------

It was once said that: 
> OP is a faggot

```
It was once said that: 
> OP is a faggot
```

## They can also be staggered.

Convo:
> fag1: hay
>> fag2: fuckoff
>>> fag1: oh...

> anon: what am i reading?

```
Convo:
> fag1: hay
>> fag2: fuckoff
>>> fag1: oh...

> anon: what am i reading?
```

### ------------------------------------ Formatting --------------------------------------- 

# H1
### H3
## H2

_italic_

**bold**

~~strikethrough~~

--- 

```
# H1
### H3
## H2

_italic_

**bold**

~~strikethrough~~

---
^Horizontal rule
```
Yes, H2 and H3 are wrong way round... 
The Horizontal rule also brakes if you do not give it a blank newline above and below it.

###Paragraph formatting
 
 
 
 
 
If you want to make multiple newline spaces that the forum engine will not just toss out for being a duplicate. you can use a hair space on each line. This is not recognized as a space character so you can get that paragraph formatting just the way you like it.
 
 
 
 
 
 Enjoy.

### ------------------------- Chan refugee bonus tip ------------------------------
 
 > Such text
 > Much meam
 
~~If you want to meme text, put a hair space character before the ">" so the forum engine does not recognize it as a quote.~~ 

 >
 >
 >

Disregard that, OP sucks cocks. You can use `\>` to do the same thing, But as pointed out by [qspitzer][5], the hair space does keep things clean on the ZeroTalk list, not that you degenerates would care for such formalitys.

\>
\>
\>

If you do not like how the forum engine makes the newline spacing bigger when doing any of the above, you can also use `>`. (thanks [eighty4][6]). This will keep the paragraph spacing tight.

>
>
>
 
 > Much point
 > Such wow
 
 
[5]:#comment_66_1Hc87xHmLsZyaGTQYnx2UmQPKwE1EmgxKX

topic.title: We are fucked.
topic.body:
Technology has now come to this point, nothing can be trusted anymore.
https://www.notjordanpeterson.com/

1565403304_1D9oYXWZH2S55PeoCFDKTqq8roNXq.body:
Just to but in, It is very common for users that use "Always TOR" to lose connection to the trackers. Can't find anyone who has explained why yet, but my guess is that the TOR network may be blocking the BitTorrent activity, shutting you out of the network.

I know Tor users frown upon using the network for P2P file shearing, So, If anyone is knowable about the Tor protocol and how peers on the network react to seeing torrent activity, it would be a big help to finding out what is going on.

> [crazylime](#comment_14_1D9oYXWZH2S55PeoCFDKTqq8roNXqZqP7n): After updating my tracker list, it appears as though I can get about 26/49 to work.  But, what doesn't work ever is connections to peers, 0 of 6000+.  Why would no peers be accessible?

Well, It may be down to timeing out. I mean, My ping to peers is 3240ms ave over Always Tor. I have a VPN, So, Im just realy testing it out to see how it works. 

But I'm turning Always Tor off now because that ping is abysmal. It would be a hell of a stress on the Tor network, having to deal with the thousands of requests BitTorrent generates with that kind of ping. This is why the Tor network users don't like P2P running over it.

Maybe it would be worth looking into useing Tribbler technolgy for the anonymization protocol. Tribler has built a tor like onion routing system that is taylored for bittorrent with some impressive results.

1565570944_1KUSKrffaR1sfLwxZUXUPshLpKhh5.body:
The account ID system is based on Certs. Basically, Your cert has a public and privet key. You keep your privet key and give sites your public one. This verifies that you are who you say you are without the need to have a password, or for the site to have the need to keep account information.

Sites in this system would not be able to keep accounts, as, all the data of the site, even its databases, have to be stored on all computers that load it. So having a database that says (user = John; Pass = Doe;) would be pointless, as anyone that access the site would have that information at hand.

Certs however do not have this problem, as, the user can sign the information with their privet key, and the sites' logic can check this signature information with the public key to verify you are who you say you are.

You can also use this system to make User only page content. As the content can be encrypted with the public key and sent out to all users to store, but it's content can only be opened and read by the user with that privet key.

This is why the "very confusing "account/id" system" is the way it is.

> [bvcfbfbcbcvd](#comment_5_1KUSKrffaR1sfLwxZUXUPshLpKhh5PXWm7): @montecarlo: I thought it was obvious that by "Google", I meant that they could easily block ZeroNet in their browser which everyone (except I) uses. Nothing about the network itself.

What are they going to do, Block LocalHost? I meen, All the browser is doing is presenting a HTML front end GUI served from the LocalHost on port 43110. Most of the magic is going on in the ZeroNet Aplication, with the browser haveing no control over it. Unless they skim the code looking for ZeroNet elements to block the connection, there is not much they can do.

Mainly because they like to take a shadow inhibiter approach. E. G: Use an engine bug or use an API they know other browsers do not play nicely with in their own products, to encourage people to do things there way. An outright element scan to trigger a connection drop to the localhost would be way too blatent.

> [trevorlaneray](#comment_44_12eXcQ1ojAbyCoCcMQ3JAKi73wgcJrjow3): But you raise a good point... How would one go about establishing a "verified" tag on a decentralized platform?

You could have it so when you claim verification on a username, you submit a public key and all look alike character variations of that username is blacklisted as not available for verification. 

If you sign the post with your privet key and the username matches, the verified symbol appears, but, if you do not sign the post, it does not.

I mean, you guys started the flaming well enough until @trevorlaneray arrived and civility and productive conversation broke out. For the record: I don't want a "verified" check, it is the mark of lower intelligence and high aggression over on Twatter and I'll be a monkey's uncle if I get one here...

What can we say, This is interesting tech. Your troll post posed an interesting conundrum regarding how one could even do such a thing on a decentralized trustless network. ;)

1565639606_1Hb5zuymuNq9rhYhhoYuAPGMXpxsp.body:
Counter point. Although it is true that all users have the same opportunity to run the network, all are not equal. Only users that have a good home network connection and proper set up to reduce ping, will be preferentially picked as peers to connect to over less capable connections.

Ping, Data Capacity and Mbps is the currency the network treasures, and as such, The ones with the grater amount has more power over the network.

Does the Networking Masterrace not like you? You just got put into the mute blackhole, and your posts will not be seeded by them.
Does the Networking Masterrace like you, Or is indifrent to your exsistence? Well, good news, Your posts have been given blessing and now your post will be served by your gracious BestNet overlords.

Net Neutrality inherently does not exist on ZeroNet because of this, so it can not be said to operate in a way compatible with the mantra. From each according to his ability, to each according to his needs.

Food for thought ay? ;)

1565899855_141zS75MupoDVjN4p7ivG9pXUXjAm.body:
Tor is already bundled on windows. That is, Zero can send all traffic over the tor network. It would be good however to have "Always Tor" on by default, with the option to disabling it giving a pop-up that states.

...Warning...
Disabling Always Tor will expose your IP to the internet as the technology uses BitTorrent to distribute sites.
This will allow people to link the sites you use/host to your IP Address based on what you are seeding.

We do not recommend doing this unless you have another means of anonymizing your IP, such as a VPN or SOCKS Proxy, that you are sure is properly configured to not leak your identity.

> [xianc78](#comment_49_141zS75MupoDVjN4p7ivG9pXUXjAm9jLBQ):   Given how Linux software is installed, I don't think we can bundle Tor with the Linux bundle.

> [bigbadbob](#comment_285_1CLhLYdMKjXtium9yjuRkSnFvPfdoUTXAj): I was never on 8chan but its certainly true for 4chan. Anyone who posts anything must be rawdoggin it. Every vpn i tried or tor node was banned, so i would only ever just lurk. I just assumed people who post didn't care or understand.

I got a 4chan pass one year, and i could VPN and post. Haveing a pass circumvents IP block lists for posting, witch makes sense, as thay have another way to identify you even if you was VPNing onto the site. 

The only thing they do ban you for then is telling others that this is a thing. I got a 8 day ban for telling someone in the VIP board about it, but it was just an IP block, so i took it as a warning. So, I just hopped onto another server on my VPN, Re-linked my pass to that IP and kept posting.

Basically: This is a thing we will let you do, But we are going to say don't do it, and ask that you don't tell others to do this thing that you can do but can't. ;)

1565885910_1KUSKrffaR1sfLwxZUXUPshLpKhh5.body: You again. I remember you was posting about how you don't want to mute people because it does not go far enough, stopping people from interacting with things you post completely. Why the change of hart there champ?

To actually give you an answer: The site sends a mute request to the ZeroNet API. That "animation" from the zero icon at the top left is the ZeroNet API asking the user if you want it to execute the request.

It is done so bad zites can't just execute a shadow ban attack, spamming a bunch of user mute requests to the API without the users knowledge.
